title: The Product Launch Decision
subtitle: Navigate critical decisions as a product manager launching a new feature
context: You're a product manager at a growing SaaS company. After months of development, your team is ready to launch a major new feature. The stakes are high - this feature could significantly impact customer retention and revenue. Several decisions need to be made in the coming days.

decisions.prompt: How will you approach the initial launch?
decisions.context: Your team has completed development, but there are still some edge cases that haven't been fully tested.

options.label: Ship to everyone immediately
options.description: Launch the feature to all customers at once. Move fast and fix issues as they arise.

options.label: Staged rollout with beta testers
options.description: Start with a small group of engaged users who've agreed to test new features, then gradually expand.

options.label: Wait for comprehensive testing
options.description: Hold the launch until all edge cases are thoroughly tested and documented. Quality over speed.

outcomes.title: Launch Day Chaos
outcomes.description: The feature launches to all customers. By midday, support tickets are flooding in - an edge case you hadn't fully tested is affecting about 15% of users. The team scrambles to fix it while managing customer complaints. The fix takes 3 days, and some customers have churned.
learnings: Speed without testing can create more work than it saves
Customer trust is hard to rebuild once damaged
Edge cases often affect more users than initial estimates suggest

outcomes.title: Controlled Success
outcomes.description: Beta testers catch a significant bug in the first week. Your team fixes it before the wider rollout. When the feature goes live to all customers, it works smoothly. Beta testers feel valued and become advocates for the new feature.
learnings: Engaged early users become product champions
Staged rollouts de-risk launches without excessive delays
Finding issues early is far cheaper than finding them late

outcomes.title: Missed Window
outcomes.description: Two weeks into comprehensive testing, a competitor launches a similar feature. While your feature eventually launches bug-free, you've lost the first-mover advantage. Customer perception is that you're playing catch-up rather than leading.
learnings: Perfect can be the enemy of good in competitive markets
Testing has diminishing returns - at some point, real-world feedback is more valuable
Market timing matters alongside product quality
